название: Этичный хакинг и защита информации: первые шаги
описание: этот курс посвящен ctf (capture the flag) и практической информационной безопасности . вы погрузитесь в мир этичного хакинга, научитесь находить уязвимости, эксплуатировать их и защищаться от атак. обучение построено на реальных кейсах и интерактивных заданиях, чтобы вы могли сразу применять знания на практике. почему стоит выбрать этот курс? 🔹 практика с первых уроков – никакой «воды», только реальные задачи, похожие на ctf-соревнования. 🔹 от основ к продвинутым техникам – курс подходит как новичкам, так и тем, кто хочет систематизировать знания. 🔹 актуальные угрозы – разбираем современные атаки и методы защиты. 🔹 готовые лаборатории – не нужно настраивать сложные среды, всё работает в браузере или в предоставленных виртуальных машинах. 🔹 подготовка к соревнованиям – курс поможет уверенно стартовать в ctf (jeopardy, attack-defense, mixed). цели курса 🎯 научить основам информационной безопасности через призму ctf-задач. 🎯 дать навыки поиска и эксплуатации уязвимостей (web, crypto, forensics, pwn, reversing). 🎯 объяснить, как защищать системы на основе реальных примеров. 🎯 подготовить к участию в ctf-соревнованиях и началу карьеры в кибербезопасности. что приобретут обучающиеся? ✔ навыки взлома и защиты – от базовых атак до продвинутых техник. ✔ опыт решения ctf-задач – криптография, стеганография, обратная разработка, веб-эксплуатация. ✔ понимание работы хакеров – чтобы эффективнее защищаться. ✔ сертификат – подтверждение полученных знаний (если предусмотрено платформой). ✔ доступ к сообществу – обсуждение задач, разборы решений, поддержка единомышленников.

название: How to Choose the Right Backup Power Option for Your Home
описание: power outages can hit when you least expect them. whether it’s a storm, a grid failure, or just living somewhere remote, losing electricity can quickly go from inconvenient to urgent. choosing the right backup power option for your home isn’t just smart—it’s essential. this guide will help you figure out what you actually need and what setup makes the most sense for your lifestyle. step #1 – identify your power priorities start with a simple list: what do you absolutely need to keep running if the power goes out? think about the essentials first—refrigerator, lights, phone chargers, maybe a medical device, or your wi-fi router. if you work from home or rely on powered equipment, add that, too. the goal is to focus on what’s truly important, not necessarily everything you’d like to power. for example, running the air conditioner might be nice, but if you’re on a limited budget, it may not be a top priority. once you’re clear on your must-haves, you’ll have a better idea of what your backup system needs to cover instead of getting overwhelmed with options that are too large or not powerful enough. step #2 – calculate your energy needs look at the wattage of the devices on your list. this information is usually printed on a sticker or label, or you can find it online. add up the wattage for all the essentials you want to run at the same time. if something cycles on and off, like a fridge, include that in your total. don’t forget to think about how long you’ll need to use each device. if you’re unsure how to convert watts to watt-hours (which measures energy over time), there are simple calculators online that do the math for you. this step gives you a clearer idea of what capacity you’ll need when you start comparing backup power systems. step #3 – explore available backup power options there’s a wide range of choices out there—from gas generators to battery-based systems and solar-powered solutions. gas generators are easy to find and can power heavy-duty appliances, but they’re loud, need fuel, and require outdoor use. portable power stations, on the other hand, are quieter, safer to use indoors, and perfect for running electronics or small appliances. if you’re looking for something eco-friendly, solar generators paired with battery storage offer a renewable, quiet solution. many people are leaning toward battery-based systems for convenience, especially those that can be expanded over time. they work great whether you live in a house, apartment, or rv. step #4 – compare short-term and long-term costs it’s easy to look at price tags and assume a cheaper system is the best option. but think about the ongoing costs, too. gas generators might cost less upfront, but you’ll keep paying for fuel and maintenance. battery systems tend to cost more initially, but they’re quieter, cleaner, and require very little upkeep. also, consider how often you expect to use the system. if outages are rare, a small backup may be enough. but if you live in an area with regular blackouts or off-grid needs, investing in a system that’s reliable and scalable will pay off down the line. step #5 – choose the system that fits your lifestyle if you live in a home with lots of space and want something that powers your whole house, a large-capacity system like the ecoflow delta pro ultra can be integrated directly into your home’s electrical setup. if you’re renting, traveling in an rv, or just want something portable to charge essentials, smaller portable power stations offer flexibility without installation. think about how you live, how mobile you need your system to be, and how much control you want over your energy use. some systems let you monitor usage from an app, store solar energy during the day, and automatically kick in during an outage.
